front.title: Signalling Path MTU via BGP Attributes

section.name: Introduction
section.t: To help achieve the highest possible MTU end-to-end, this document extends BGP-4 to aid network operators in this effort by signalling the MTU for each route.
A new BGP capability declaring the link MTU is specified in .

An optional, non-transitive attribute, called "Path MTU", is specified in . It allows network administrators to use Path MTU in their route selection. The main focus/applicability is the Internet (IPv4 and IPv6 unicast route advertisements).

The BGP attribute defined in this document can be attached to prefixes from Multiprotocol BGP IPv4/IPv6 Labeled Unicast ( ). Usage of this BGP attribute for other Address Family Identifier (AFI) / Subsequent Address Family Identifier (SAFI) combinations is not defined herein but may be specified in future specifications.

section.name: Terminology
section.t: The terms "MTU" in this document signifies the Maximum Transmission Unit for a given BGP address family.

section.name: Assumptions
section.t: All MTU values are measured in bytes at layer 3.
Each BGP speaker is configured with the following values:

ul.li: Link MTU: Maximum packet size the BGP speaker can process through its own ASN
Fallback MTU: Maximum packet size if no per-route information is supplied (usually 1500 bytes)

section.t: It is also assumed that the FIB used by the BGP speaker supports per-destination MTU values, such as is the case for the Linux kernel.

section.name: Theory of Operation
section.t: A BGP speaker advertises the link MTU capability as follows:

ul.li: The link MTU capability is announced only if a BGP speaker understands the Path MTU route attribute
The link MTU capability is set to the configured local Link MTU, as defined above

section.t: When establishing a session with a peer, a BGP speaker does the following:

ul.li: If the peer advertises the link MTU capability, compute the effective link MTU as the minimum of the locally configured link MTU and the link MTU advertised by the peer
If the peer link MTU is different from the local link MTU, an implementation SHOULD emit a warning
If the session does not have an effective link MTU, then this part is ignored.

li.t: Otherwise, if the route already has a path MTU attribute

ul.li: If the effective link MTU is smaller than the value in the attribute, update the path MTU value in the attribute to the value of the effective link MTU
Leave the origin ASN in the attribute as-is

li.t: If the route does not already have a path MTU attribute, add a new attribute with

ul.li: The MTU value set to the effective link MTU
The ASN set to the local ASN

section.t: When installing a route into the FIB:

ul.li: If the route has no path MTU attribute, install the route with the fallback MTU.
If the ASN appearing in the path MTU attribute is different from the originating ASN from the AS path, ignore the attribute and install the route with the fallback MTU.
Otherwise, compute the route MTU as the minimum of the effective link MTU and the value in the path MTU attribute, and install the route with this route MTU.

section.name: Link MTU Capability
section.t: A new BGP capability with ID XXX is defined with the following contents:

dl.dd: 2 bits; flags are reserved for future use and MUST be 0.
14 bits; The BGP speakers MTU for the link a BGP session is being negotiated over.

section.name: Path MTU Attribute
section.t: A new optional, non-transitive BGP attribute with ID XXX is defined with the following contents:

dl.dd: 32 bits; the first ASN along the path to support this attribute.
2 bits; flags are reserved for future use and MUST be 0.
14 bits; The MTU for a route.
